properties.Name: Bond

Columns.Name: BondId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Product.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberOfBondsIssued
Columns.Description: The total number of bonds issued.

Columns.Name: IssuePriceAmount
Columns.Description:
The price at which the bond is issued.

Ex:
Zero Coupon Bonds are issued at a discount and mature at Par ($1,000

Columns.Name: OriginalIssueDiscount
Columns.Description:
Some bonds are issued at a discount to the Par value. In the case of a municipal bond, the accretion of the value from the original issue discount price to Par is considered tax-free income. 

Throughout the life of the bond, the cost basis of the bond will increase based on a formula known as constant yield to maturity (CYM). This means that if you buy a bond with an OID priced at 96, and sell it 5 years later at 98, you will not incur a capital gain as long as the accreted value of the bond based on CYM is 98 or greater

Columns.Name: ParValue
Columns.Description:
The principal amount of a bond or note due at maturity.

The value of a bond as given on the certificate or instrument.

Par value is important for bonds because the interest paid on bonds is based on a percentage of a bond's par value.

Par value, also known as Face value, is the value of the bond at maturity. Almost all bonds have a $1,000 par value. Bond prices are almost always quoted as a percentage of par, so you will hear prices such as 99 or 101.5. These refer to the percentage of $1,000, and mean $990 and $1,015 per bond respectively.

Columns.Name: PrincipalAmount
Columns.Description: The face amount of a bond payable at maturity.

Columns.Name: FixedInterestRate
Columns.Description:
Interest is the money the issuer pays to the bondholder at specified times throughout the life of the bond. 

The stated interest rate of a bond is usually referred to as the coupon rate. 

Most bonds pay interest semi-annually (twice per year).

A coupon is the stated interest rate for a bond. Most bonds have a fixed coupon that does not change during the life of the bond. Most bonds have two coupon payments per year. 

For example, a bond with a 5.0% coupon will pay $25 twice per year, for total interest of $50 which is 5.0% of the face value of the bond (almost all bonds have a face value of $1,000).

Columns.Name: BondCapPercentage
Columns.Description: The highest level interest rate that can be paid on a floating-rate debt instrument.

Columns.Name: FloatingInterestRateCalculationMethodDescription
Columns.Description: The method or calculation by which the floating interest rate for the bond is determined.

Columns.Name: FloatingInterestRateTieToIndexName
Columns.Description: The name of the index to which the bond floating interest rate is tied.

Columns.Name: FloatingInterestCapRate
Columns.Description: Floating interest rate bonds may have upper and lower limits which are known as the 'collar' and cap and floor rates respectively.

Columns.Name: FloatingInterestFloorRate
Columns.Description: Floating interest rate bonds may have upper and lower limits which are known as the 'collar' and cap and floor rates respectively.

Columns.Name: CouponPaymentAmount
Columns.Description: A amount of each coupon that will be paid when presented for the Bond.

Columns.Name: NominalYieldPercentage
Columns.Description: The percentage of interest paid on the face value of the bond.

Columns.Name: DateOfIssue
Columns.Description:
The dated date is the date the bond is issued and starts to accrue interest

The date on which a Bond is issued and when Interest accrues to the bondholder. Used in the context of stocks to refer to the date Trading begins on a new Stock issued to the public.

Columns.Name: OfferingDate
Columns.Description: Date On which a new set of Bonds will first be sold to the public.

Columns.Name: MaturityDate
Columns.Description:
The date on which the principal amount of a bond is due and payable.

Maturities can range from as little as one day to as long as 30 years.

Columns.Name: CallDate
Columns.Description: A date before maturity, specified at issuance, when the Issuer of a Bond may Retire part of the bond for a specified Call price.

Columns.Name: RedemptionDate
Columns.Description: The date on which a bond is scheduled to mature or be redeemed.

Columns.Name: RetractableDate
Columns.Description:
With a retractable bond, an investor owns a longer term bond with the right to "retract" it at a specific date. 

Consider an investor that believes that interest rates will rise and bond prices will fall, but is not willing or able to sell out of bonds completely. 

This investor can buy a longer term retractable bond which behaves initially as a similar term long term bond. As interest rates rise the bond falls in price. 

Once its price is low enough, it will begin to behave as a short term bond and its price fall will be much less than a normal long term bond. At worst, the investor can retract it at the retraction date and receive the par amount back to reinvest.

Columns.Name: MaturityPeriodInMonths
Columns.Description:
The maturity period expressed in years for the associated Bond.

Note:
This could be derived from the Maturity Date.

Columns.Name: CallableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that carries the right to redeem it before the scheduled maturity date.   

The first date when an issuer may call bonds is specified in the prospectus of every issue having a call provision.

See BOND CALL SCHEDULE entity.

Columns.Name: CallPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The price, specified at issuance, at which the Issuer of a Bond may Retire part of the bond at a specified Call date.

Columns.Name: CallPremiumAmount
Columns.Description: Premium in price above the Par value of a Bond or share of Preferred stock that must be paid to holders to redeem the bond or share of preferred stock before its scheduled maturity date.

Columns.Name: CallProtectionPeriod
Columns.Description:
A bond may offer Call Protection for a specific period of time (Call Protection Period) expressed in months.

After that the issuer may redeem the bond if it chooses.

Columns.Name: CallProtectionPeriodStartDate
Columns.Description:
The period start date of the call protection period.

Call protection is a feature of some callable bonds that established an initial period when the bonds may not be called.

Columns.Name: CallProtectionPeriodEndDate
Columns.Description:
The period end date of the call protection period.

Call protection is a feature of some callable bonds that established an initial period when the bonds may not be called.

Columns.Name: ConversionPrice
Columns.Description: The dollar value at which convertible bonds can be converted into common stock.

Columns.Name: ConversionDate
Columns.Description: The date upon which the conversion may first be exercised.

Columns.Name: ConversionFinancialProductId
Columns.Description: The financial product that the bond has the option to be converted to.

Columns.Name: ConversionRatio
Columns.Description: The ratio of bond to financial product that may be converted.

Columns.Name: InsuredBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
Municipal bonds that are insured against default by a municipal bond insurance company, which will make interest and principal payments when due if the issuer of the bonds defaults on its obligations.    

The bond insurer pays a premium to the insurance company.

Some municipal bonds are insured as to principal and interest by large bond insurance firms. The insurance firms are generally large with considerable financial strength. Therefore, any bond that is insured by one of the major insurers will carry a top credit rating from the major rating services, regardless of the issuer's credit strength.

Columns.Name: BondInsuranceProviderName
Columns.Description: The name of the organization that is guaranteeing principal and interest on the bonds if they are insured.

Columns.Name: SecuredBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A secured bond is backed by collateral that may be sold by the bondholder to satisfy a claim should the bond issuer fail to pay interest and principal when due.

Columns.Name: RedeemableBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond without a Call Feature, which is the issuer's right to redeem the bond before maturity or a Redemption Privilege, which is the holder's right to sell the bond back to the issuer before maturity.

Columns.Name: CouponBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that is issued with coupons that must be detached and presented to a paying agent or the issuer for semiannual interest payments.

These are essentially bearer bonds because whoever presents the coupons is entitled to the interest.

Coupon bonds are being replaced by registered bonds, which pay interest via electronic transfers or credits.

Columns.Name: GuaranteedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond on which the principal and interest are guaranteed by a firm other than the issuer.

Columns.Name: SubjectToAmtIndicator
Columns.Description:
In addition to calculating regular income tax, taxpayers are also required to calculate tax liability using the AMT method. The taxpayer then pays the higher of the tax calculated by the two methods. 

Some municipal bonds are subject to AMT, meaning that if you pay AMT, the interest earned on these bonds is taxable under the AMT calculation. 

Other municipal bonds are not subject to AMT, meaning that even if you pay taxes using the AMT method, interest from non-AMT municipals will not be taxable.

Columns.Name: SplitCouponBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond or debt instrument that begins as a zero-coupon bond and then converts to an interest-paying bond at a specific future date.

These bonds are of advantage to issuers because they do not pay out cash interest for several years.    They are attractive to investors because they can lock in a reinvestment rate for many years and receive cash interest.

Columns.Name: DeferredInterestBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that pays interest at a later date, which means that the interest is automatically reinvested at a fixed rate.

Zero coupon bonds are examples.

Columns.Name: JointBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that has more than one obligor or that is guaranteed by a party other than the issuer.

Aka 'Joint And Several Bond'

Columns.Name: JunkBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond with a credit rating of BB or lower by a rating agency.

Junk bonds are issued by companies without long track records or with questionable credit strength.    They are a popular means of financing takeovers.

Institutions with fiduciary responsibilities are regulated in acquiring or trading junk bonds.

The two major credit rating services rate bonds as to their credit worthiness. Bonds that are rated at or above "Baa" by Moody, or "BBB" by S&P are said to be investment grade bonds. Bonds rated lower than these ratings are said to be high yield (junk) bonds.

Columns.Name: PaymentInKindBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that pays interest and/or dividends in the form of additional bonds of the same kind.

Payment-in-kind bonds are frequently used in takeover financing in place of cash and are very speculative in nature.

Columns.Name: OptionalPaymentBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond whose principal and/or interest are payable at the option of the holder in one or more foreign currencies (or in the domestic currency).

Columns.Name: CollateralTrustBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A corporate debt security that is backed by other securities, held by a bank or similar trustee and issued by parent legal entities that are borrowing against the securities of wholly owned subsidiaries.

Columns.Name: AccrualBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A Bond on which Interest accrues but is not paid to the Investor during the time of accrual. The amount of Accrued interest is added to the remaining Principal of the bond and is paid at maturity.

Columns.Name: GeneralObligationBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
Indicates that the associated bond is secured by a pledge of the issuer's full faith, credit and taxing power.

The interest and principal payments for a municipal bond are typically either guaranteed by the issuer or by the revenue from a specific project. If they are guaranteed by a specific project, the bondholder is relying on revenue from the project to pay principal and interest, and the bonds are known as revenue bonds. If the issuer guarantees the repayment of principal and interest, the bonds are known as a general obligation (often referred to as G.O.) of the issuer.

Columns.Name: PreRefundedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Sometimes an issuer desires to pay off a bond in order to remove the debt from its books. However, the bond may not be immediately callable, and the issuer can not redeem the bonds at its discretion. In this case the issuer may deposit sufficient funds with a trustee into an escrow account so that the trustee can use the funds to pay all interest and principal on a specified call date in the future. In this case, the bond is said to be pre-refunded, and the pre-refunded date should be viewed as the date that the bond will be redeemed.

Columns.Name: ListedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Most corporate bonds trade over-the-counter - that is to say that they do not trade on an exchange. There are a small number of bonds that do trade on the NYSE, and these bonds are said to be "listed" on the exchange.

Columns.Name: IndexedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Bond whose payments are linked to an index, e.g., the consumer price index (reference financial product).

Columns.Name: SinkerBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond with a sinking fund associated with it.    

Sinking funds are money set aside by an issuer of bonds on a regular basis for the specific purpose of redeeming the bond.

Columns.Name: SubordinatedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Bonds that fall after others in priority of claims on the entity in the case of financial distress.

Columns.Name: DiscountedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Debt sold for less than its Principal value. If a Discount Bond pays no coupon, it is called a zero Coupon bond.

Columns.Name: SinglePaymentBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond that makes only one payment of principal and interest.

Columns.Name: PriorLienBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond that has precedence over another bond of the same issuing company even though both classes of bonds are equally secured.

Columns.Name: StrippedBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that is separated into two components:  period interest payments and principal repayment

Each of the interest payments and the principal repayment are stripped apart by a brokerage firm and sold individually as Zero-Coupon securities.

Columns.Name: ExtendableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
An extendible bond gives its holder the right to "extend" its initial maturity at a specific date or dates. 

The investor initially purchases a shorter term bond combined with the right to extend its term to a longer maturity date. An investor purchases an extendible bond to have the ability to take advantage of potentially falling interest rates without assuming the risk of a long term bond. 
As interest rates fall, the price of a shorter term bond rises less than the price of a longer term bond. 
This means the extendible bond begins to behave or "trade" as a longer term bond. On the other hand, if interest rates rose, the extendible bond would behave as a shorter term bond.

Columns.Name: InvestmentGradeBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond that is rated within the top four categories by Moody's or Standard & Poor's.

Columns.Name: RetractableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
With a retractable bond, an investor owns a longer term bond with the right to "retract" it at a specific date. 

Consider an investor that believes that interest rates will rise and bond prices will fall, but is not willing or able to sell out of bonds completely. 

This investor can buy a longer term retractable bond which behaves initially as a similar term long term bond. As interest rates rise the bond falls in price. 

Once its price is low enough, it will begin to behave as a short term bond and its price fall will be much less than a normal long term bond. 
At worst, the investor can retract it at the retraction date and receive the par amount back to reinvest.

Columns.Name: PutBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Put bonds are issued with an option that entitles bondholders to force the issuer to buy back the bonds on specific dates (put the bonds back to the issuer).

Columns.Name: ActiveBondIndicator
Columns.Description: Corporate debt instruments that trade frequently on the floor of the NYSE are classified as active and are assigned certain privileges. Included are substantial issues of established corporations and most convertible bonds.

Columns.Name: FloaterBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A Bond whose Interest rate varies with the Interest rate of another Debt instrument, e.g., a bond that has the interest rate of the Treasury bill +.25%.

Columns.Name: SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionIndicator
Columns.Description: Some municipal bonds are issued with an extraordinary redemption provision which gives the issuer the right to call the bonds under certain circumstances. The circumstances could range from natural disasters to cancelled projects to almost anything else.

Columns.Name: SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionDescription
Columns.Description: Some municipal bonds are issued with an extraordinary redemption provision which gives the issuer the right to call the bonds under certain circumstances. The circumstances could range from natural disasters to cancelled projects to almost anything else.

Columns.Name: EmbeddedOptionIndicator
Columns.Description: A provision within a bond given either the issuer or the bondholder an option to take some action against the other party - such as a call option.

Columns.Name: EmbeddedOptionDescription
Columns.Description: A provision within a bond given either the issuer or the bondholder an option to take some action against the other party - such as a call option.

Columns.Name: ExemptFromFederalTaxesIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the bond is exempt from federal taxes.

Columns.Name: ExemptFromStateTaxesIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the bond is exempt from state taxes for residents of the state where the bond was issued.

Columns.Name: ExemptFromLocalTaxesIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the bond is exempt from local taxes for residents of the state where the bond was issued.

Columns.Name: RegisteredBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond whose owner is registered with the issuer or its agent.

Transfer of ownership can only be accomplished when the securities are properly endorsed by the registered owner.

Columns.Name: AdjustableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that is issued for outstanding bonds when recapitalizing a corporation that faces bankruptcy.    

The actual authorization for the exchange is given by the bondholders who consider adjustment bonds to be more attractive.    

Adjustable bonds promise to pay interest only to the extend earned by the corporation - without accrued interest.

Columns.Name: FloatingRateBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond whose interest rate can float.

Columns.Name: CommodityBackedBondIndicator
Columns.Description: A bond that is tied to the price of an underlying commodity normally used as a hedge.

Columns.Name: AdjustmentBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
When recapitalizing a corporation that faces bankruptcy, if the bondholders approve, adjustment bonds are issued in replacement of outstanding bonds.   Bondholders usually will authorize the issuance of adjustment bonds as they are deemed a lesser evil than a corporate bankruptcy. An adjustment bond assures payment of interest only if earned by the corporation. This is one of
 the characteristics of an income bond.

Columns.Name: NonCallableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond that cannot be redeemed at the option of the issuer.

A bond may offer Call Protection for a specific period of time.   After that the issuer may redeem the bond if it chooses.

Columns.Name: IrredeemableBondIndicator
Columns.Description:
A bond without a Call Feature, which is the issuer's right to redeem the bond before maturity or a Redemption privilege, which is the holder's right to sell the bond back to the issuer before maturity.

Also known as a perpetual bond.

Columns.Name: GicsSubIndustryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bond Sector associated with the bond.

Columns.Name: InterestRateTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Interest Rate Type.

Columns.Name: BondMaturityCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bond Maturity Categorization.

Columns.Name: BondCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bond Category.

Columns.Name: BondPurposeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the bond purpose.

Columns.Name: BondDeliveryFormId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bond Delivery Form.

Columns.Name: BondStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bond status.

Columns.Name: BondPayFrequencyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bond Pay Frequency.

Columns.Name: BondTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a type of bond.

Columns.Name: BondGradeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the bond grade.

Columns.Name: BondPriorityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bond priority.

Columns.Name: RedemptionFeatureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Redemption Feature.

Columns.Name: TaxExemptionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Tax Exemption Type.

Properties.DerivedModelEntityInfo:
{"entityDirectives":{"baseEntityReference":{"name":"Bond","path":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond"},"description":"A bond is a debt instrument in which the issuer promises to pay to the bondholder principal and interest according to the terms and conditions of the bond. 

A certificate of indebtedness in which the issuer (borrower) promises to pay the bondholder (creditor) a specified amount of interest for a specified time period and to repay the debt at maturity

Obligations that are due in more than one year are classified as bonds whereas if the debt is for less than one year, it is called a "note." 

Bondholders are creditors of the issuer and they do not have ownership privileges. A bond may be registered either by issuing certificates in the bondholder's name, book-entry or in bearer certificates. 

A bond is an interest-bearing or discounted corporate or government security.

A bond obligates the issuer to pay the bondholder a specific sum of money at specific intervals and to repay the principal amount of the loan upon maturity.

A bond is simply an IOR by an organization to repay a sum of money at a specific interest rate over a pre-defined period of time.    Most bonds pay a fixed rate of interest.    Variable bonds are the exception in that they pay varying amounts of interest.

A certificate of indebtedness in which the issuer (borrower) promises to pay the bondholder (creditor) a specified amount of interest for a specified time period and to repay the debt at maturity. Obligations that are due in more than one year are classified as bonds whereas if the
 debt is for less than one year, it is called a "note." Bondholders are creditors of the issuer and
 they do not have ownership privileges. A bond may be registered either by issuing certificates in the bondholder's name, book-entry or in bearer certificates. 

There are many different kinds of bonds and different methods of evidencing bond ownership.

 The most common types are: 

- Secured bonds are backed by collateral that may be sold if the issuer fails to pay interest and  principal when they are due. 

- Unsecured bonds or debentures are only backed by the full faith and credit of the issuer.
There is no specific collateral. 

- Convertible bonds give holders the right to exchange the bonds for other securities of the issuer at a future date, under prescribed conditions.

When the principal of the bond is paid off, the bond is said to be redeemed. This could be derived from the Maturity Date.","isNullable":true,"name":"MaturityPeriodInMonths"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that carries the right to redeem it before the scheduled maturity date.   

The first date when an issuer may call bonds is specified in the prospectus of every issue having a call provision.

See BOND CALL SCHEDULE entity.","isNullable":true,"name":"CallableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallPriceAmount"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"The price, specified at issuance, at which the Issuer of a Bond may Retire part of the bond at a specified Call date.","isNullable":true,"scale":2,"name":"CallPriceAmount"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallPremiumAmount"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Premium in price above the Par value of a Bond or share of Preferred stock that must be paid to holders to redeem the bond or share of preferred stock before its scheduled maturity date.","isNullable":true,"scale":2,"name":"CallPremiumAmount"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallProtectionPeriod"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":3,"description":"A bond may offer Call Protection for a specific period of time (Call Protection Period) expressed in months.

After that the issuer may redeem the bond if it chooses.","isNullable":true,"scale":0,"name":"CallProtectionPeriod"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallProtectionPeriodStartDate"},"dataType":"date","dateFormat":"YYYY-MM-DD","description":"The period start date of the call protection period.

Call protection is a feature of some callable bonds that established an initial period when the bonds may not be called.","isNullable":true,"name":"CallProtectionPeriodStartDate"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CallProtectionPeriodEndDate"},"dataType":"date","dateFormat":"YYYY-MM-DD","description":"The period end date of the call protection period.

Call protection is a feature of some callable bonds that established an initial period when the bonds may not be called.","isNullable":true,"name":"CallProtectionPeriodEndDate"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ConversionPrice"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"The dollar value at which convertible bonds can be converted into common stock.","isNullable":true,"scale":2,"name":"ConversionPrice"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ConversionDate"},"dataType":"date","dateFormat":"YYYY-MM-DD","description":"The date upon which the conversion may first be exercised.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConversionDate"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ConversionFinancialProductId"},"dataType":"long","description":"The financial product that the bond has the option to be converted to.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConversionFinancialProductId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ConversionRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"The ratio of bond to financial product that may be converted.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ConversionRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"InsuredBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Municipal bonds that are insured against default by a municipal bond insurance company, which will make interest and principal payments when due if the issuer of the bonds defaults on its obligations.    

The bond insurer pays a premium to the insurance company.

Some municipal bonds are insured as to principal and interest by large bond insurance firms. The insurance firms are generally large with considerable financial strength. Therefore, any bond that is insured by one of the major insurers will carry a top credit rating from the major rating services, regardless of the issuer's credit strength.","isNullable":true,"name":"InsuredBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondInsuranceProviderName"},"dataType":"string","dataTypeLength":256,"description":"The name of the organization that is guaranteeing principal and interest on the bonds if they are insured.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondInsuranceProviderName"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SecuredBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A secured bond is backed by collateral that may be sold by the bondholder to satisfy a claim should the bond issuer fail to pay interest and principal when due.","isNullable":true,"name":"SecuredBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"RedeemableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond without a Call Feature, which is the issuer's right to redeem the bond before maturity or a Redemption Privilege, which is the holder's right to sell the bond back to the issuer before maturity.","isNullable":true,"name":"RedeemableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CouponBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that is issued with coupons that must be detached and presented to a paying agent or the issuer for semiannual interest payments.

These are essentially bearer bonds because whoever presents the coupons is entitled to the interest.

Coupon bonds are being replaced by registered bonds, which pay interest via electronic transfers or credits.","isNullable":true,"name":"CouponBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"GuaranteedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond on which the principal and interest are guaranteed by a firm other than the issuer.","isNullable":true,"name":"GuaranteedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SubjectToAmtIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"In addition to calculating regular income tax, taxpayers are also required to calculate tax liability using the AMT method. The taxpayer then pays the higher of the tax calculated by the two methods. 

Some municipal bonds are subject to AMT, meaning that if you pay AMT, the interest earned on these bonds is taxable under the AMT calculation. 

Other municipal bonds are not subject to AMT, meaning that even if you pay taxes using the AMT method, interest from non-AMT municipals will not be taxable.","isNullable":true,"name":"SubjectToAmtIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SplitCouponBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond or debt instrument that begins as a zero-coupon bond and then converts to an interest-paying bond at a specific future date.

These bonds are of advantage to issuers because they do not pay out cash interest for several years.    They are attractive to investors because they can lock in a reinvestment rate for many years and receive cash interest.","isNullable":true,"name":"SplitCouponBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"DeferredInterestBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that pays interest at a later date, which means that the interest is automatically reinvested at a fixed rate.

Zero coupon bonds are examples.","isNullable":true,"name":"DeferredInterestBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"JointBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that has more than one obligor or that is guaranteed by a party other than the issuer.

Aka 'Joint And Several Bond'","isNullable":true,"name":"JointBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"JunkBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond with a credit rating of BB or lower by a rating agency.

Junk bonds are issued by companies without long track records or with questionable credit strength.    They are a popular means of financing takeovers.

Institutions with fiduciary responsibilities are regulated in acquiring or trading junk bonds.

The two major credit rating services rate bonds as to their credit worthiness. Bonds that are rated at or above "Baa" by Moody, or "BBB" by S&P are said to be investment grade bonds. Bonds rated lower than these ratings are said to be high yield (junk) bonds.","isNullable":true,"name":"JunkBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"PaymentInKindBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that pays interest and/or dividends in the form of additional bonds of the same kind.

Payment-in-kind bonds are frequently used in takeover financing in place of cash and are very speculative in nature.","isNullable":true,"name":"PaymentInKindBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"OptionalPaymentBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond whose principal and/or interest are payable at the option of the holder in one or more foreign currencies (or in the domestic currency).","isNullable":true,"name":"OptionalPaymentBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CollateralTrustBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A corporate debt security that is backed by other securities, held by a bank or similar trustee and issued by parent legal entities that are borrowing against the securities of wholly owned subsidiaries.","isNullable":true,"name":"CollateralTrustBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"AccrualBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A Bond on which Interest accrues but is not paid to the Investor during the time of accrual. The amount of Accrued interest is added to the remaining Principal of the bond and is paid at maturity.","isNullable":true,"name":"AccrualBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"GeneralObligationBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Indicates that the associated bond is secured by a pledge of the issuer's full faith, credit and taxing power.

The interest and principal payments for a municipal bond are typically either guaranteed by the issuer or by the revenue from a specific project. If they are guaranteed by a specific project, the bondholder is relying on revenue from the project to pay principal and interest, and the bonds are known as revenue bonds. If the issuer guarantees the repayment of principal and interest, the bonds are known as a general obligation (often referred to as G.O.) of the issuer.","isNullable":true,"name":"GeneralObligationBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"PreRefundedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Sometimes an issuer desires to pay off a bond in order to remove the debt from its books. However, the bond may not be immediately callable, and the issuer can not redeem the bonds at its discretion. In this case the issuer may deposit sufficient funds with a trustee into an escrow account so that the trustee can use the funds to pay all interest and principal on a specified call date in the future. In this case, the bond is said to be pre-refunded, and the pre-refunded date should be viewed as the date that the bond will be redeemed.","isNullable":true,"name":"PreRefundedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ListedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Most corporate bonds trade over-the-counter - that is to say that they do not trade on an exchange. There are a small number of bonds that do trade on the NYSE, and these bonds are said to be "listed" on the exchange.","isNullable":true,"name":"ListedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"IndexedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Bond whose payments are linked to an index, e.g., the consumer price index (reference financial product).","isNullable":true,"name":"IndexedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SinkerBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond with a sinking fund associated with it.    

Sinking funds are money set aside by an issuer of bonds on a regular basis for the specific purpose of redeeming the bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"SinkerBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SubordinatedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Bonds that fall after others in priority of claims on the entity in the case of financial distress.","isNullable":true,"name":"SubordinatedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"DiscountedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Debt sold for less than its Principal value. If a Discount Bond pays no coupon, it is called a zero Coupon bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"DiscountedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SinglePaymentBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that makes only one payment of principal and interest.","isNullable":true,"name":"SinglePaymentBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"PriorLienBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that has precedence over another bond of the same issuing company even though both classes of bonds are equally secured.","isNullable":true,"name":"PriorLienBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"StrippedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that is separated into two components:  period interest payments and principal repayment

Each of the interest payments and the principal repayment are stripped apart by a brokerage firm and sold individually as Zero-Coupon securities.","isNullable":true,"name":"StrippedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ExtendableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An extendible bond gives its holder the right to "extend" its initial maturity at a specific date or dates. 

The investor initially purchases a shorter term bond combined with the right to extend its term to a longer maturity date. An investor purchases an extendible bond to have the ability to take advantage of potentially falling interest rates without assuming the risk of a long term bond. 
As interest rates fall, the price of a shorter term bond rises less than the price of a longer term bond. 
This means the extendible bond begins to behave or "trade" as a longer term bond. On the other hand, if interest rates rose, the extendible bond would behave as a shorter term bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"ExtendableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"InvestmentGradeBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that is rated within the top four categories by Moody's or Standard & Poor's.","isNullable":true,"name":"InvestmentGradeBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"RetractableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"With a retractable bond, an investor owns a longer term bond with the right to "retract" it at a specific date. 

Consider an investor that believes that interest rates will rise and bond prices will fall, but is not willing or able to sell out of bonds completely. 

This investor can buy a longer term retractable bond which behaves initially as a similar term long term bond. As interest rates rise the bond falls in price. 

Once its price is low enough, it will begin to behave as a short term bond and its price fall will be much less than a normal long term bond. 
At worst, the investor can retract it at the retraction date and receive the par amount back to reinvest.","isNullable":true,"name":"RetractableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"PutBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Put bonds are issued with an option that entitles bondholders to force the issuer to buy back the bonds on specific dates (put the bonds back to the issuer).","isNullable":true,"name":"PutBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ActiveBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Corporate debt instruments that trade frequently on the floor of the NYSE are classified as active and are assigned certain privileges. Included are substantial issues of established corporations and most convertible bonds.","isNullable":true,"name":"ActiveBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"FloaterBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A Bond whose Interest rate varies with the Interest rate of another Debt instrument, e.g., a bond that has the interest rate of the Treasury bill +.25%.","isNullable":true,"name":"FloaterBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Some municipal bonds are issued with an extraordinary redemption provision which gives the issuer the right to call the bonds under certain circumstances. The circumstances could range from natural disasters to cancelled projects to almost anything else.","isNullable":true,"name":"SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionDescription"},"dataType":"string","dataTypeLength":2048,"description":"Some municipal bonds are issued with an extraordinary redemption provision which gives the issuer the right to call the bonds under certain circumstances. The circumstances could range from natural disasters to cancelled projects to almost anything else.","isNullable":true,"name":"SubjectToExtraordinaryRedemptionDescription"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"EmbeddedOptionIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A provision within a bond given either the issuer or the bondholder an option to take some action against the other party - such as a call option.","isNullable":true,"name":"EmbeddedOptionIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"EmbeddedOptionDescription"},"dataType":"string","dataTypeLength":2048,"description":"A provision within a bond given either the issuer or the bondholder an option to take some action against the other party - such as a call option.","isNullable":true,"name":"EmbeddedOptionDescription"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ExemptFromFederalTaxesIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Indicates whether the bond is exempt from federal taxes.","isNullable":true,"name":"ExemptFromFederalTaxesIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ExemptFromStateTaxesIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Indicates whether the bond is exempt from state taxes for residents of the state where the bond was issued.","isNullable":true,"name":"ExemptFromStateTaxesIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"ExemptFromLocalTaxesIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Indicates that the bond is exempt from local taxes for residents of the state where the bond was issued.","isNullable":true,"name":"ExemptFromLocalTaxesIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"RegisteredBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond whose owner is registered with the issuer or its agent.

Transfer of ownership can only be accomplished when the securities are properly endorsed by the registered owner.","isNullable":true,"name":"RegisteredBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"AdjustableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that is issued for outstanding bonds when recapitalizing a corporation that faces bankruptcy.    

The actual authorization for the exchange is given by the bondholders who consider adjustment bonds to be more attractive.    

Adjustable bonds promise to pay interest only to the extend earned by the corporation - without accrued interest.","isNullable":true,"name":"AdjustableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"FloatingRateBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond whose interest rate can float.","isNullable":true,"name":"FloatingRateBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"CommodityBackedBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that is tied to the price of an underlying commodity normally used as a hedge.","isNullable":true,"name":"CommodityBackedBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"AdjustmentBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"When recapitalizing a corporation that faces bankruptcy, if the bondholders approve, adjustment bonds are issued in replacement of outstanding bonds.   Bondholders usually will authorize the issuance of adjustment bonds as they are deemed a lesser evil than a corporate bankruptcy. An adjustment bond assures payment of interest only if earned by the corporation. This is one of
 the characteristics of an income bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"AdjustmentBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"NonCallableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond that cannot be redeemed at the option of the issuer.

A bond may offer Call Protection for a specific period of time.   After that the issuer may redeem the bond if it chooses.","isNullable":true,"name":"NonCallableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"IrredeemableBondIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A bond without a Call Feature, which is the issuer's right to redeem the bond before maturity or a Redemption privilege, which is the holder's right to sell the bond back to the issuer before maturity.

Also known as a perpetual bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"IrredeemableBondIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"GicsSubIndustryId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Bond Sector associated with the bond.","isNullable":false,"name":"GicsSubIndustryId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"InterestRateTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of an Interest Rate Type.","isNullable":false,"name":"InterestRateTypeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondMaturityCategoryId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Bond Maturity Categorization.","isNullable":false,"name":"BondMaturityCategoryId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondCategoryId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Bond Category.","isNullable":false,"name":"BondCategoryId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondPurposeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of the bond purpose.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondPurposeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondDeliveryFormId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Bond Delivery Form.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondDeliveryFormId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondStatusId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a bond status.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondStatusId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondPayFrequencyId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Bond Pay Frequency.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondPayFrequencyId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a type of bond.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondTypeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondGradeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of the bond grade.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondGradeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"BondPriorityId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a bond priority.","isNullable":true,"name":"BondPriorityId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"RedemptionFeatureId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Redemption Feature.","isNullable":true,"name":"RedemptionFeatureId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Bond.cdm.json/Bond","name":"TaxExemptionTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Tax Exemption Type.","isNullable":true,"name":"TaxExemptionTypeId"}]}}}
Properties.Description:
A bond is a debt instrument in which the issuer promises to pay to the bondholder principal and interest according to the terms and conditions of the bond. 

A certificate of indebtedness in which the issuer (borrower) promises to pay the bondholder (creditor) a specified amount of interest for a specified time period and to repay the debt at maturity

Obligations that are due in more than one year are classified as bonds whereas if the debt is for less than one year, it is called a "note." 

Bondholders are creditors of the issuer and they do not have ownership privileges. A bond may be registered either by issuing certificates in the bondholder's name, book-entry or in bearer certificates. 

A bond is an interest-bearing or discounted corporate or government security.

A bond obligates the issuer to pay the bondholder a specific sum of money at specific intervals and to repay the principal amount of the loan upon maturity.

A bond is simply an IOR by an organization to repay a sum of money at a specific interest rate over a pre-defined period of time.    Most bonds pay a fixed rate of interest.    Variable bonds are the exception in that they pay varying amounts of interest.

A certificate of indebtedness in which the issuer (borrower) promises to pay the bondholder (creditor) a specified amount of interest for a specified time period and to repay the debt at maturity. Obligations that are due in more than one year are classified as bonds whereas if the
 debt is for less than one year, it is called a "note." Bondholders are creditors of the issuer and
 they do not have ownership privileges. A bond may be registered either by issuing certificates in the bondholder's name, book-entry or in bearer certificates. 

There are many different kinds of bonds and different methods of evidencing bond ownership.

 The most common types are: 

- Secured bonds are backed by collateral that may be sold if the issuer fails to pay interest and  principal when they are due. 

- Unsecured bonds or debentures are only backed by the full faith and credit of the issuer.
There is no specific collateral. 

- Convertible bonds give holders the right to exchange the bonds for other securities of the issuer at a future date, under prescribed conditions.

When the principal of the bond is paid off, the bond is said to be redeemed. Bonds can be redeemed at maturity, or on a call date or put date.

Bondholders are creditors of the issuer and they do not have ownership privileges. A bond may be registered either by issuing certificates in the bondholder's name, book-entry or in bearer certificates.
